column9:
865733: Load the relevant packages, the Election Campaign 2022 dataset and the Election Campaign codebook.
In this quiz we will explore how a usual suspect sociodemographic variable, age, is related to political attitudes.
As our dependent variable / response variable, the quiz will use four different survey questions capturing political attitudes.
The names of the four response variables are:

Extra_FaithInPublicHospitalSystem
Extra_CompensateInflation
Extra_ImmigrationIsAThreat
Extra_UnemployedDontDoEnough

The labels are somewhat indicative of what the response variables capture. But it is always a good idea to use the codebook to understand the survey questions and scaling properly! I have been to one too many presentations, where the "direction" of the regression coefficient was misunderstood since the scaling of the regressor or response variable was misinterpreted.
Use the codebook to answer: What does a value of "4" mean on the Extra_CompensateInflation variable?
column11: 865734: When can you join datasets together for analysis in R?
column13: 865735: Why is Z-standardization useful in data analysis?

column17: 865761: On a scale from 0 (the worst possible quiz for this course) to 10 (the best possible quiz for this course), how would you rate the quiz, that you have just completed?
column19:

column23:
865741: Before running a regression analysis it is always important to get a sense of the data we are analysing.
For example, by running a histogram on the age variable we see two respondents are much older than 100 years. This is highly unlikely, so we will filter out these respondents.
Use the same code to inspect the variable Extra_UnemployedDontDoEnough in a histogram with a binwidth of 1.
Which of the two statements describes the distribution better?
column25:

Find the correlation coefficient between age and Extra_UnemployedDontDoEnough
For the cor-function to work, we must first inspect if there are any NA's on the attitude-variable. If there are, please remove these and then run the analysis.
What is the correlation coefficient? (write your answer with three digits)

column29:
865755: No matter which attitude variable you investigated before, the coefficient would be significant. Does this mean we are ready to publish our first paper?
Not exactly. A good rule of thumb is that if you cannot visualize a result, it is not substantially important, even though it might be statistically significant. This is because with a large enough N, and enough statistical power, even the smallest statistical relationships can be statistically significant.
Therefore you should now visualize the relationship between age and the idea that the unemployed don't do enough in a jittered scatter plot.
Do you think the relationship between the two variables is substantially important? Describe the relationship between the two variables and give your verdict!
column31:
865760: The dataset also includes a variable for political trust, meaning how much the respondent trusts politicians. Higher values on a scale from 1 to 5 means more trust.
Run two regressions, one predicting the idea that the unemployed don't do enoughusing age, the other using political trust.
Yet, run them such that the strength of the coefficients is comparable. This means that we have to rescale the variables and make sure that the two models are run with the same observations, if one or both the regressor variables have missingness.

column29:
The correlation between the two variables is statistically significant. This relationship is represented by a negative slope of -0.002, meaning that for every year older a person is, we can assume a -0.002 decrease in the opinion that the unemployed don't do enough, measured on a scale of 1-5, where 1 represents "completely disagree" and 5 represents "completely agree".

However, for a just full point on this scale, with our found slope, we would be looking at a difference across around 500 years. Therefore we can gather that the practical significance of this relationship is not that strong and for every year the opinion only barely changes.

column47:
When observing the relationship between age and faith in the Public Hospital System, a few things become immediately apparent.

First of all, there is a noticeably larger group of respondents that are somewhat satisfied with the public health system, closely followed by another large group that is completely satisfied with this service. Looking at age alone, there are 3 age groups concentring a larger proportion of respondents: 20 to 25 years old, 50 to 55 years old, and 65 to 75 years old. 

Now for the relationship between the variables; there is a relatively similar distribution of the age of participants across levels of satisfaction with the public health system. However, there is a slightly bigger concentration of older respondants satisfied with the public health system. This relationship explains the positive model prediction: a slight right skewed response seems to infer a positive correlation between age and faith in the public health system. 

However, with a largely scattered and balanced distribution of responses, the correlation is minimal, shown by the very horizontal model line.

* The relationship between age and faith in the public hospital system appears weakly positive, as indicated by the slight upward slope of the trend line.

* The responses are categorical (1 to 5), which could suggest that respondents rate their faith in the hospital system using discrete values.

* There is a large spread of data at each level of faith in the system across different ages, but the trend line indicates that as age increases, there is a slight tendency for people to have more faith in the system.

column47:
The statistical analysis of the relationship between age and faith in the public hospital system reveals that, while the results are statistically significant, the practical relevance of the findings is minimal. First, the correlation between these two variables is 0.1161, indicating a weak positive relationship. This suggests that as individuals age, there is a slight increase in their faith in the public hospital system. However, this effect is minimal, as the strength of the correlation is far from substantial.

Further, looking at the regression analysis, the R-squared value of 0.0135 indicates that only 1.35% of the variance in faith in the public hospital system can be explained by age. In other words, age has a very limited impact on individuals' attitudes toward the public hospital system, and the overwhelming majority of variation in these attitudes remains unexplained by this single predictor. Moreover, the 

 coefficient for age is 0.0067911, implying that for each additional year of age, the level of faith in the public hospital system increases by just 0.00679 units. Considering that the intercept (constant) in the model is 3.5736, this change is negligible, as it indicates a very small shift in attitudes over time. Even with large sample sizes, such a tiny change would have little meaningful impact in a real-world setting. Finally, while the p-value < 0.01 confirms that the relationship between age and faith in the public hospital system is highly unlikely to be due to chance, statistical significance alone does not imply practical importance.
